tagrelator.collect.flickr
Class FlickrCollector

java.lang.Object
  tagrelator.collect.flickr.FlickrCollector

public class FlickrCollector
extends java.lang.Object

with this class you can connect to the Flickr API, search for Photos, and collect some data from the photos in the search results.
the collected data is stored in a incremental fashion, which means you can process the results in several runs,
because it is a time costly process.
see the documentation of the collect method, for further information

FlickrCollector

public FlickrCollector(java.lang.String anApikey,
                       java.lang.String aSharedSecret)
to access the Flickr API you need an API key, and for some things the shared secret you can get both for free on http://www.Flickr.com/api"

Method Detail

collect

private boolean collect(java.util.TreeSet<java.lang.String> terms,
                        java.lang.Integer samplesizeIn,
                        java.lang.String storeToOpen,
                        java.lang.String storeToWrite)
collects photo data for the words in the terms parameter, and saves them to file

Parameters:
terms - the words for which a search on Flickr is executed, one search per term
samplesizeIn - determines how many photos in the searchresult are processed
storeToOpen - a file that has been written on a previous run of the FlickrCollector, if "" a default is used
the processing of the Results is resumed at point where it stopped last time.
for now the actual search for the word is performed on every run, the cycling through the results is handled by indexes, which means you always work on up to date results, but you may miss or double process, some photos because they changed position in the results, due to deletion or addition of matching photos on flickr no actual bitmap data is downloaded here, so there should be no bandwith issue.
what is saved is the photo_id, userId of the owner, url to the photo, tagset of the photo
storeToWrite - give a filename to store the results in, if "" a default is used

collectV2

public boolean collectV2(java.util.TreeSet<java.lang.String> terms,
                         java.lang.Integer samplesizeIn,
                         java.lang.String aCorpusFolderRead,
                         java.lang.String aCorpusFolderWrite)
                  throws java.io.IOException
collects photo data for the words in the terms parameter, and saves them to file

Parameters:
terms - the words for which a search on Flickr is executed, one search per term
samplesizeIn - determines how many photos in the searchresult are processed
aCorpusFolderRead - a file that has been written on a previous run of the FlickrCollector, if "" a default is used
the processing of the Results is resumed at point where it stopped last time.
for now the actual search for the word is performed on every run, the cycling through the results is handled by indexes, which means you always work on up to date results, but you may miss or double process, some photos because they changed position in the results, due to deletion or addition of matching photos on flickr no actual bitmap data is downloaded here, so there should be no bandwith issue.
what is saved is the photo_id, userId of the owner, url to the photo, tagset of the photo
aCorpusFolderWrite - give a filename to store the results in, if "" a default is used
Throws:
java.io.IOException

repairCollect

public boolean repairCollect(java.lang.String pathtoFolder)
a costly function to ensure that all terms in corpus have same samplesize, if possible in firstpass all files in corpus are openend to get the amount of contained samples the max samplesize is determined in the second pass the all files are openend again and samples are collected until max samplessize, unless there simply arent max samplesize samples

Parameters:
pathtoFolder - the CorpusFolder

openStore

public SearchtermList openStore(java.lang.String fileName)
opens a saved processed results object. if there is none it creates a new one

Parameters:
fileName - the results file that should be opened, or created
